title: Research
text:
Revealing the Scope of the Smaller Donor Revolution: Rising Activism in U.S. State Politics. With James G. Gimpel



Washington State University

Spring 2022 CAS Undergraduate Research Grant Pullman, WA Undergraduate Research, Scholarship, or Creative Activity Support Award ($2,300)

Conducted survey experiment, Evaluating New Media Consumption and Clarity over the spring of 2022 with 1,200 respondents
Conduct data analysis and draw conclusions from survey data

Summer 2021 CAS Undergraduate Research Grant Pullman, WA Dick Miyagishima Student Support Scholarship in the Liberal Arts ($2,000)

Conducted a pilot survey experiment, Evaluating New Media Consumption and Clarity over the summer of 2021 through the fall of 2021 with 400 respondents nationwide
Conduct data analysis and draw conclusions from survey data

title: Isabelle M. Gibson
text:
Biography
I am a Government and Politics Ph.D. student at the University of Maryland. I study American Politics, my research interests are American behavior, race and ethnic politics, political psychology and political media. I earned my B.A. in Political Science at Washington State University in 2022, double majored in Political Science and Philosophy.


CV


Areas of Interest

Political Media and Communication
Black Politics
Race and Ethnic Politics



Degrees

B.A. - Political Science, Washington State University 2022



Awards

2021-05-07
CAS Summer 2021 Undergraduate Research, Scholarship, or Creativity Activity Support - Washington State University
2021-12-15
CAS Spring 2022 Undergraduate Research, Scholarship, or Creativity Activity Support - Washington State University



Conferences

2024
APSA 2024 Annual Meeting and Exhibition, Philadelphia, PA
2022
Washington State University, Pullman, WA Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities (SURCA)

title: GVPT 729B Final Project
text:
My github page for this project here
My final project aims to analyze media framing and sentiment in coverage of BLM protest. This project does the following:

Identify common words/themes across a variety of articles gathered from NewsAPI.
Visualize the words/themes with word clouds and bar plots
Conduct a sentiment analysis to provide insights into the tone of the articles overall, negative or positive.

With my account with NewsAPI I gather multiple articles related to “Black Lives Matter protests”. To prepare the text data for analysis, I combine the title, description, and content fields from the articles into a single column called text for analysis.

I then tokenize the combined text column into individual words using the untest_tokens function from tidy text and create blm_words.
I remove all the stop words and irrelevant words like http, amp, etc.




Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


Loading required package: RColorBrewer


Here I begin to build a word count to calculate the frequencies across all of the articles. Then I generate a word cloud that visualizes the most frequent words.

I also group the word frequencies by the news source as well. I looped through each news source to generate individual word clouds, visualizing how different outlets emphasize different terms and words.












[1] "Word Cloud for Naples Daily News"









[1] "Word Cloud for BBC News"









[1] "Word Cloud for The Atlantic"

Here is where I created a Bar Plot to visualize the top words frequencies









Lastly, I conduct a sentiment analysis. Using Bing Lexicon, I match words from the tokenized blm_words with the bing sentiment lexicon, which classifies words as positive or negative. It counts the number of positive and negative words in the dataset.

The bar chart shows the distribution of positive and negative sentiment words across the entire corpus.

title: GVPT 729B Final Project
text:
My github page for this project here
My final project aims to analyze media framing and sentiment in coverage of BLM protest. This project does the following:

Identify common words/themes across a variety of articles gathered from NewsAPI.
Visualize the words/themes with word clouds and bar plots
Conduct a sentiment analysis to provide insights into the tone of the articles overall, negative or positive.

With my account with NewsAPI I gather multiple articles related to “Black Lives Matter protests”. To prepare the text data for analysis, I combine the title, description, and content fields from the articles into a single column called text for analysis.

I then tokenize the combined text column into individual words using the untest_tokens function from tidy text and create blm_words.
I remove all the stop words and irrelevant words like http, amp, etc.




Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


Loading required package: RColorBrewer


Here I begin to build a word count to calculate the frequencies across all of the articles. Then I generate a word cloud that visualizes the most frequent words.

I also group the word frequencies by the news source as well. I looped through each news source to generate individual word clouds, visualizing how different outlets emphasize different terms and words.

Here is where I created a Bar Plot to visualize the top words frequencies









Lastly, I conduct a sentiment analysis. Using Bing Lexicon, I match words from the tokenized blm_words with the bing sentiment lexicon, which classifies words as positive or negative. It counts the number of positive and negative words in the dataset.

The bar chart shows the distribution of positive and negative sentiment words across the entire corpus.
